titlestmt.titleproper: Finding aid to the Brigitte Jordan papers SSC.MS.00634
titlestmt.author: Ellice Amanna

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-02-14 13:17:08 -0500.

change.item: This record was migrated from InMagic DB Textworks to ArchivesSpace.

did.unittitle: Brigitte Jordan papers

physdesc.extent: (15 record cartons, 4 legal size document boxes)
(1,048 files: digital images, video, and documents)

did.abstract: In the 1970s, Brigitte Jordan conducted seminal work in the study of cross-cultural birth practices, including home birth and hospital birth, in the Yucatan and in Holland, Sweden and the United States, resulting in publication of the book Birth in Four Cultures (1983). She taught and conducted research for many years at the university level, where her interests focused on the dynamics of change in the medical systems of developing countries. Her papers consist of audiovisual materials, images, publications, presentations, and research files for an anthropological study conducted by Jordan, of cross-cultural childbirth practices in Mexico, Holland, Sweden, and the U.S., circa 1970s, published in her book Birth in Four Cultures (1983). Included are videotapes of hospital and home births and verbatim transcriptions in Spanish, Dutch, Swedish, with English translations. Of special interest are films of indigenous midwifery practices, including several births Jordan attended as apprentice to a village midwife in the Yucatan. Also included are a series of pen and ink drawings of a Mexican midwife attending a pregnant women, field notes and other research materials.
did.langmaterial: Spanish, Dutch, Swedish, German, Portuguese, Italian, English

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Brigitte Jordan conducted seminal work in the study of cross-cultural birth practices in the 1970s, including home birth and hospital birth, in the Yucatan and in Holland, Sweden and the United States, resulting in publication of the book Birth in Four Cultures (1983). She taught and conducted research for many years at the university level, where her interests focused on the dynamics of change in the medical systems of developing countries. In 1988, Jordan began working as a corporate anthropologist, and her research and consulting interests evolved to include the changing nature of work under the impact of new communication and information technologies and the consequent transformation of ways of life, societal institutions, and global economies. A sought-after speaker and leader of executive workshops, Jordan was the author of many scholarly and technical publications. Brigitte (Gitti) Muller Jordan was born in Passau, Germany, in 1937 and grew up there during World War II. Her parents were Gertrude Frank Muller, who died in 1944 when Jordan was seven, and Josef Karl Muller. She married Richard Jordan in 1958, and theyt had three children: Wayne (b. 1959), Susan (b. 1960), and Kimsey (b. 1961); the couple divorced in 1968. Jordan earned her B.A. and M.A. degrees in Anthropology at California State University at Sacramento, and her Ph.D. in Social Science/Anthropology from University of California at Irvine in 1975. She died at home on May 24, 2016 of pancreatic cancer. Her website states, "she chose to meet the cancer on her own terms, refusing medical intervention, embracing hospice care, and remaining as physically and mentally active as humanly possible until the end."

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for use without restriction beyond the standard terms and conditions of Smith College Special Collections.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: This collection is comprised of the following accessions, some of which may not have accession records. Accession numbers: 08S-107, 2018-S-0027. Accessions were received on the following dates: 2008-12-01, 2018-05-24.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Video tapes may be reproductions of original films.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: The a/v materials look fine but the paper documents have extensive water damage, including mold. The materials in Boxes 6-9 have been minimally stabilised by drying them out and refoldering them, but everything should be photocopied asap.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Brigitte Jordan papers, Sophia Smith Collection, SSC-MS-00634, Smith College, Northampton, Mass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Brigitte Jordon papers consist of audiovisual materials, images, publications, presentations, and research files for an anthropological study, conducted by Jordan, of cross-cultural childbirth practices in Mexico, Holland, Sweden, and the U.S., circa 1970s, published in her book Birth in Four Cultures (1983). Included are videotapes of hospital and home births; and verbatim transcriptions in Spanish, Dutch, Swedish, with English translations. Of special interest are films of indigenous midwifery practices, including several births Jordan attended as apprentice to a village midwife in the Yucatan. Also included are a series of pen and ink drawings of a Mexican midwife attending a pregnant women, field notes and other research materials. Most recent accession includes materials from her work in Palo Alto with the XEROX Corporation at the Palo Alto Research Center, teaching materials from her anthropology classes, and numerous materials from workplace ethnography studies conducted by Jordan.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: To the extent that he owned copyright to the works of his late wife Brigette Jordan, Robert Irwin has dedicated copyright in her materials to the public domain. This agreement is governed by a CC0 (Creative Commons 1.0 Universal) public domain dedication. Copyright in other items in this collection may be held by their respective creators. For instances which may regard materials in the collection not created by Brigette Jordan, researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights and obtaining approval from them. Researchers do not need anything further from Smith College Special Collections to move forward with their use.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: This collection contains materials received from the donor in digital form, as well as digitized materials, that are not currently available online. Please consult with Special Collections staff to request access to this digital content.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Brigitte Jodon died in 2016. This collection was closed during her lifetime; no processing was permitted during her liufetime. Papers from earlier collections are as of yet unprocessed.

did.unittitle: Brigitte Jordan papers 2018-S-0027

physdesc.extent: (9 record cartons and 1 legal document box)
(1,048 files: digital images, video, and documents)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Papers consist of audiovisual materials, images, presentations and research files for an anthropological study, conducted by Jordan, of cross-cultural childbirth practices in Mexico, Holland, Sweden, and the U.S., circa 1970s, published in her book Birth in Four Cultures (1983). This accession also includes materials from her work in Palo Alto with the XEROX at the Palo Alto Research Center, teaching materials from her anthropology classes, and numerous materials from workplace ethnography studies conducted by Jordan.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Held by Jordan's widower, Robert Irwin, after her death and transferred to Smith College by him.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: This collection contains materials received from the donor in digital form that are not currently available online. Please consult with Special Collections staff to request access to this digital content.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The digital files received on compact disks and floppy disks have been copied to networked storage by Special Collections staff for preservation and access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Brigette Jordan's electronic files consist primarily of digital images, and few small videos, labelled "Peneng pix," from 2003. Also includes are articles and other documents related to her research and consulting work, dated 1993-99. For more information see the detailed file list.

phystech.p: CD01 contains QuarkXPress file (desktop publishing document), which requires QuarkXPress, or Adobe InDesign wih Q2ID plugin, to read. There are also images on disc.

did.unittitle: Brigitte Jordan presenting: digital images
Brigitte Jordan website: "Lifescapes"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The archived website of Brigitte Jordan (http://www.lifescapes.org/) was first captured in 2016 and subsequent periodic captures are scheduled. The site includes biographical information, a bibliography, full text of her papers, information about workshops and speaking engagements.
